titleStmt.title: plain away
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript is a partial transcription of Whitman's article, "Art-Singing and Heart-Signing," published in the Broadway Journal on 29 November 1845, as reported by Whitman in the manuscript. As indicated by Bergman, Noverr and Recchia in The Journalism. Volume I: 1834–1846 (512), this article was later published as "Heart-Music and Art-Music" in the Brooklyn Evening Star on 14 November 1846, and part of it appeared in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle with the title of "Music that IS music" on 4 December 1846.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Art-Singing and Heart-Singing
bibl.orgName: The Bayley-Whitman Collection, Ohio Wesleyan University, Delaware, OH

body.p: plain away. The sight of them, as they are, puts one in mind of health and fresh air in the country at sunrise,—the dewy, earthy fragrance that comes up then in the moisture, and touches the nostrils more gratefully than all the perfumes of the most ingenious chemist

These hints we throw out rather as suggestive of a train of thought to other and more deliberate thinkers than we—and not as the criticisms of a musical connoisseur. If they have pith in them, we have not much doubt others will carry them out. If not, we at least know they are written in that true wish for f benefitting the subject spoken of, which should characterize all such essays
